newsitem.title: USA: Pentagon findings on Gulf War illness criticized.
newsitem.headline: Pentagon findings on Gulf War illness criticized.

text.p: There is "substantial evidence" linking chemical agents and the kinds of illnesses experienced by Gulf War veterans, the New York Times reported on Sunday, quoting a government study to be released this month.

The report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, criticised a special White House panel and the Defence Department for finding that Iraqi chemical weapons were probably not responsible for the illnesses, the Times said.

The government report said the Pentagon should not rule out the possibility that Iraqi biological weapons, especially afla-toxins, any of a group of potent liver carcinogens, might be responsible for some ailments reported by the estimated 80,000 Gulf War veterans who have sought special medical checkups, the newspaper said.

"It also criticised the Pentagon for trying to discount another potential risk, a tropical disease spread by parasites that produces symptoms that might not surface for years, and questioned whether pesticides had contributed to their health problems," the Times said.
Both the White House and the Pentagon told the newspaper they would not respond to the criticism until the report was officially released.

"It supports the idea that we should take the Gulf War research programme away from the Pentagon and give it to someone who really wants to find some answers," Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican, told the Times. Shays has been critical of the Defence Department's handling of the probe.

The General Accounting Office report also said that "clouds of chemical weapons might have reached American troops as a result of the aerial bombing of Iraqi chemical plants and storage depots early in the war," the Times reported.
